description: From Middle English complexion (“temperament”), from Old French complexion (French complexion), from Medieval Latin complexiō (“complexion, constitution”), from complector, past participle complexus (“to entwine, encompass”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete, medicine) The combination of humours making up one's physiological "temperament", being either hot or cold, and moist or dry.
examples: “Indeed, sir,” answered the lady, with some warmth, “I cannot think there is anything easier than to cheat an old woman with a profession of love, when her complexion is amorous; and, though she is my aunt, I must say there never was a more liquorish one than her ladyship.  […]

entries.meaning: The quality, colour, or appearance of the skin on the face.

examples: It was a little unfortunate that the fib unfibbed gave their consultations something the complexion of that close understanding which exists between penitent and confessor.

entries.meaning: Outlook, attitude, or point of view.
examples: But the purely marginal jottings, done with no eye to the Memorandum Book, have a distinct complexion, and not only a distinct purpose, but none at all; this it is which imparts to them a value.

entries.meaning: (loanword, especially in scientific works translated from German) An arrangement.
examples: Second there is the level at which the energy or velocity components of each molecule are specified. He calls this a Komplexion, which we translate literally as complexion.

verbs.description: complexion (third-person singular simple present complexions, present participle complexioning, simple past and past participle complexioned)

examples: From the pale refinement of her genteel heroine to the sallow complexioning of poor white trash, Stowe colors her narrative with the hues of the body.
